description:
A great new addition to San Francisco coffee scene. The coffee is actually really good. I would say better than even Blue Bottle. 

The cafe has a warehouse feel to it. It's open and well lit during the day. At night this could be a spot fit for a date. 

They do lack breakfast items. When I visited only cookies were on display during breakfast time.
author: Ahmed F.

description:
Really good drinks. Thank you Sextant for making good stuff

Im coming next time in my pajamas
author: Nat Y.

description:
This place is around the corner from my garage (confusingly called "The Garage") and so I'll usually pop in to fuel up before the long walk across SoMA to get to work.

They have the most futuristic bathroom system which is computer controlled and has some sort of queuing system built-in. I'm not sure if this is actually useful or just a fun use of venture capital money, but I enjoyed it.

Last time I was here, I tried the Wired Gandhi, which is their version of a dirty chai. Like all dirty chais, it was a confusing drink to consume but had the desired effect, which was to dramatically increase the level of caffeine in my blood.

The cafe itself is spacious with a pleasant wooden decor and friendly staff. I'll be back!
author: Sunil S.

description: Had the absolute best pumpkin spice latte at this place recently. There was real pumpkin in it, which was a nice touch. The espresso and the milk mix was spot-on. Definitely going back here again!
author: J. M.

description:
Easy walk from Civic Center Station. Decent amount of seating, and overall a cool spot. Wifi is free.

Had the iced latte a few times. I admit I'm no coffee expert but I always enjoy them. Not too sweet, not bitter or burnt. 

A couple pastries are available. I really liked the almond croissant, I wasn't expecting there to be an almond paste in the middle. 

Staff has always been kind, no complaints. 

Also, cool bathrooms. Everything is touchless automatic and you need to scan a QR code (printed from a nearby tablet) to get in. Sounds silly, but it's the little things! 

Perfect for catching up with friends or sitting solo and crunching out some work.
author: Mika S.

description:
Life sure gets busy. For reasons I don't need to bore you with, I've recently been spending a lot more time in the East and South Bay. Some of it by choice, some of it not really. That means taking leisurely strolls around my SoMa neighborhood don't happen nearly as often as they did before. That also means discovering and hanging out at quietly relaxing coffee spots like Sextant becomes both a pleasure and a privilege. I'm treasuring moments like these a lot more lately, and it actually helps that the neo-industrial vibe of the space fits the neighborhood like a glove, not an O.J. glove, a real one (photo: http://bit.ly/2zMaSYk).

The café and adjoining roastery are run by Kinani Ahmed, who was born and raised in Ethiopia, a fact pertinent to his business. His unique heritage informs the choice of coffee beans as they come from his country as well as Kenya and Colombia. I ordered a $3.25 cup of their signature Yirgacheffe coffee which had an unbridled richness that was most suitable for a brisk Saturday morning (photo: http://bit.ly/2BSyRqD). They offer all the standard caffeine variations as well as tea options and cookies on the counter (photo: http://bit.ly/2Ecokb8). I know now to make a beeline here whenever I'm casually walkin' the 'hood.

COFFEE - 4 stars...the Ethiopian blend is most soothing
AMBIANCE - 4.5 stars...the rustic SoMa vibe works well here, and it's pretty quiet in here
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...quietly efficient
TOTAL - 4 stars...no Sightglass pretensions here, just good Ethiopian coffee
author: Ed U.

description:
The coffee ar Sextant is really good. They have a great interior design going with lots of natural light coming in. Plenty of space to work while enjoying a perfectly made soy cappuccino. Their prices are decent too for specialty drinks with soy or nut milk.

It would be great however if they could offer some type of vegan pastries options. Everything they have had dairy unfortunately. This is a major and growing segment of the market and not offering at least one vegan option, in San Francisco, is just out of touch. Hopefully they can figure it out. I'll still go there for coffee. It's good stuff.
author: Theart P.

description: The barista working this afternoon was snappy and rude. He was probably just having a tough day but I felt it was uncalled for to take it out on a paying customer. I decided it was best to take my business elsewhere, so I just turned around and walked out. Coffee is on every corner, so I'll go somewhere that has nice people wielding the beans. No one has time for pompous barista-zillas.
author: Ernie A.

description:
I live a block up from Sextant and thus make it my coffee stop quite often. I normally get the dirty chai the "Wired Gandhi", theirs has a far higher chai flavor which is what I'm constantly seeking from every chai I sip. But if you're anything like me, and don't like too sweet, you may ask them to put a little less chai in the drink, and it makes all the difference. Still one of my fave chai spots. The regular lattes and cappuccinos are good too - their Ethiopian blend is suuuuper smooth and smoky.
The decor is really cool and looks like reclaimed wood with an industrial feel. Great quiet-ish place if you wanna get some work done!
author: Farrah N.

description:
Stopped  by here when I was in the area and looking for a cup of coffee.  This place is pretty cool.  It's decor is modern, simple, and pretty.  It's also a pretty good spot to work -- it's very quiet.  So if you're looking to have a convo, maybe not the spot -- everyone will hear you.  

I got a cappuccino and it had a beautiful design on top and was very good.  

I would recommend this spot if you are local or in the area.  Staff is very friendly, and spot is very cute.  (Note: location is borderline sketch)
author: Michelle S.

description:
Another great finding in this neighborhood that I greatly enjoyed! And this is the second time I saw a huge roaster sitting quietly inside the room (last time being Caffe Vita at LES in NYC), amazing!

Sextant coffee carried slightly less nutty flavor while maintained a lot more smooth texture, so a very different taste compared with blue bottle coffee, another renown chain in the west coast carrying a completely opposite texture.

They also have a small backyard all the way towards the end that one could enjoy the sunshine (like today).
author: Elaine H.

description:
Snappy barista as  well   Big turnoff  when i like to 
support  local  businesses
author: kavin m.

description:
I've been here a couple of times and objectively, it's a classy, nice establishment for coffee. Good for Instagram purposes if that's your thing.

However, their cookies are no bueno! Way too sweet and taste like they're from Safeway tbh. (I don't think they actually are but they're pretty bad).

I do come here for the drip coffee though which is good. Service is fast and friendly.

They have a really cool bathroom system too. They have this QR code scanner that unlocks the room which I found pretty neat (but not enough for me to change the Yelp rating).
author: Alicia L.

description:
Sextant has been on my radar since day 1.  It's 2017 and I finally made it. I haven't actually sat down to enjoy my coffee, it's always been to go. Really wish my schedule would allow me to use their outdoor patio in the back. 

I dig the industrial vibe of the exposed brick and stuff. Hipster? whatever. I like it. 

Sextant obviously does their own roasts (hence the name) and I'm a fan. If I'm here, it's usually an americano type of morning and then I take off. Baristas have always been friendly. However after multiple morning visits, I think they could be a bit more efficient making drinks. Line up multiple orders rather than take an order, make the drink, have the customer pay and carrying on ONE BY ONE. I get it that you guys aren't Starbucks (because F that chain) but maaaaaaaaaaaaan it can be incredibly slow. 

Oh if you love croissants, they carry Neighbor Bakehouse pastries! Don't skip them because they're amazing!
author: Susy C.

description: The coffee was really good. I can't remember the name of it, I wanna say it starts with Y, but thats all I know. It really woke me up! Most coffees nowadays do not wake me up. Will definitely be back!
author: John A.

description: Need a good cup and a urban backyard to crank on some work?  I did...
author: Michael R.

description:
Found it on Yelp and stopped by just because it was a block away. And I was very pleasantly surprised. 
Very good Cappuccino. Nice lounge music. A nice environment. The barista is very friendly. And the automated bathroom system is a trip! Also a very clean and spacious bathroom.
author: Fernanda T.

description:
Never had a coffee here. But i have come by and checked out the place. 

And it is perfect for getting a cup and working your butt off. Generally not packed so enough tables for you and your laptop and nice atmosphere. Love that. 

And apparently they've got a high tech bathroom.
author: Karthik M.

description: Enjoyed the aroma of a batch of beans roasting while sipping a perfectly brewed cup of coffee. The roaster himself took a moment to explain the roasting process as he sorted the beans. It's rare to find an in-house roaster without traffic and congestion in this city. Hope this doesn't change, but for now, it's a gem.
author: Theolotro T.

description:
Cute space. Really it's huge inside. Big for a coffee shop. I mean seriously large. You won't believe it.

I've been here once. It was a time unlike other times I haven't been here. Would love to tell you more but I'd have to come back and that just wouldn't be fair to either of us.

Let's just say getting the chocolate croissant, an americano, and then refilling later with a drip is a great move! But I think you and I both know that and how caffeine can affect you to the point at which you're voice is raised for no reason and the blood pressure rises and your friend across the way is a little scared by the way the drugs affect you.

5 stars cuz they didn't ask me to leave.
author: Andrew C.

description: Nice, quiet cafe to get work done. Plenty of seating on weekend. Strong WiFi. There's a cute outdoor sitting area. Not a ton of outlets so bring plenty of power on your device.
author: Claudia H.

description: $1.00 extra is outrageous for almond milk. I walked out and refused to buy any coffee.  Any milk you add costs them money.  We already extra to ha e a latte made. Adding that extra dollar is not worth it. So many other amazing beans in SOMA.  Keep waking till you find another one.  Sightglass is a favorite.
author: cheryl R.

description: I guess they make a pretty good coffee, but the space is a little dark and there are no electric outlets. It's fine, just doesn't carry any oomph that makes me excited about going there again. Also, no food.
author: John L.

description: My 1st Time here! I'm here while waiting for my car get fixed. When I walked in, I was greeted by both staff with big smile This place is nice, it has high ceiling, skylights and a patio in the back. I ordered a cappuccino and cookie. After I put my cookie plate down, I walked back to the counter to pick up my drink, then I saw the beautiful croissants. I told the cashier that I would have bought a croissant if I've seen it. She's so nice, she offered me to exchange it. I love the great service here. I highly recommend this place to anyone. I'll be back on my next oil change :-)
author: Brenda T.

description: Classy and less known coffee establishment. Usually seems pretty quiet whenever I drive by. Cold brew is excellent-has a nice full body with a hint of chicory flavor. One of the best cups of cold brew I've had in SF.
author: Ian G.

description: This was my first experience at this coffee house. I ordered some food and a coffee and sat down at a table. I was relaxing and eating my food when a man, who I believe is the owner, very rudely came over and asked if I would sit somewhere else because I was blocking the retail coffee area. Mind you, no one had even glanced at the coffee display. I said, sure I will move but no one has approached this area.  He said, " people are probably too shy to look at the coffee because I was blocking it". I let him move the table and then sat for 40 minutes finishing my coffee and still no one even glanced at the coffee display. It was his approach that put me off and why I will never go there again.
author: Derrick G.

description: Stopped in as I was walking by and grabbed a bag of the Kochere roast to try it out. The pleasant barista gave me a cup of it on the house and it is delicious. The atmosphere is quiet and uncluttered. It would be a nice place to chat, relax, or study.
author: Matthew S.

description: Fast, friendly, excellent coffee.  Wish I still lived in the hood.  The drip is top notch and the space is pretty nice.
author: Steven R.

description:
This place is okay with one fatal flaw: you have to request permission from baristas EVERY time you want to go to bathroom, they have a weird, awkward system. They will print you a QR code every time you want to go to bathroom and that printed code works only *once*. Gotta pee 15 minutes after? Too bad, gotta ask the barista again for the potty pass and s/he's going to give you weird (real or imagined) looks. This is ridiculous. 

It used to be one of my favourites for quick coffee meetings, but I try to avoid this place now, even when it's the closest. Just not worth trying to explain to my guest that you have to get a potty pass like it's kindergarten.
author: Dean M.

description:
Friendly people.
Great coffee.
Neighbor Bakehouse pastries.

Best of all is the hands free restroom from entering, doing your business, washing your hands, then to exiting.

Ask the barista for entry and they will hand you a once time use ticket.
Scan the paper.
The door will open and close on its own.
author: Evan W.

description:
Coffee: I ordered an espresso. The beans used were "Maiden Voyage" that features a syrupy, heavy body with huge notes of mixed berries, cocoa and cherry cola, per the bag description. This was one of the best tasting espressos I've had in the city. The berry notes have such a nice flavor. 

Atmosphere: Very laid back and nice looking spot. Lots of space and good decor. Music was at a good noise level meaning you can have a conversation and hear your partner well. The lighting was very nice and open in there as well.

Customer Service: There were two awesome baristas that seemed very down to earth.

Overall I had a really nice experience here. Great spot for studying and WIFI speed was great. I easily burned through 3 hours of studying here and felt really comfortable. 10/10

p.s: To those folks complaining about the bathroom system. Oh c'mon. The bathroom is HELLA nice. Yes there is only one bathroom and you need to get this QR code but they also have a key they can just hand you. The bathroom is all high tech.
author: Jimmy M.

description:
Great find where expected least!

I was visiting from the other side of town to go to COSTCO. I got there a bit early and the warehouse was still closed. It was 9:30 on Sunday morning, I had not had my first cup off coffee yet and was desperate! So I started walking the neighborhood with little expectation until I ran into a local walking his dog. I asked him if there was a cafe around, he, with an Italian or Spanish accent told me there was a good one around the corner. I must admit, hearing the endorsement in that accent gave me some hope. So I went around the corner and to my surprise I found this very nice Cafe (i.e. Sextant). I got me a cup of their regular coffee and it was pretty good. 

The space was nicely laid out, clean, and pleasant. The restroom was very clean, and the barista was very nice.

I will go back to try their espresso next time.
author: Afshin A.

description:
I've had this coffeeshop bookmarked for awhile, and I'm glad I was finally able to visit with Jayme L. Another coffee adventure in the books! The menu is very simple, but I decided to go with the Red Eye after asking the friendly barista for the description. It was 2pm in the afternoon. I needed caffeine!

At first, Jayme and I ventured to the outdoor patio that has a few chairs and some plants. Very simple look. Then we finally moved inside to one of the small tables by the entrance. This is more of a place to read or rendezvous with a friend, not so much do work. Though I wouldn't go out of my way to come back here, definitely check it out if you haven't done so already.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
So many negative reviews on here about this place but I can honestly say it's one of the most underrrated coffee shops in the city. 

I came here on a Sunday afternoon and was so glad I found this hidden gem in SOMA. The shop was empty as there was only 2-3 people there so there was plenty of seats available (Beware that there is extremely limited space with outlets for your computers - it's by the large table next to the stairs). The decor is simple with brick walls so the atmosphere was very relaxing and open. If you're expecting anything modern and freshly clean like other shops in the city (Saint Frank, Blue Bottle, Philz, etc.) then this is definitely not the space for you. I love at atmosphere because it's very similar to a lot of my Berkeley / Oakland favorites. 

The coffee was delicious and the barista was super helpful. I guess the only negative is the area that this is in. The neighborhood isn't exactly the safest so I wouldn't leave anything in your car if you're driving. I didn't have any problems finding a parking space on a Sunday afternoon though so that's a plus!
author: Tram N.

description: Loved it for the location and the FREE WI-FI!! the space is fairly large and it was easy enough to nab my own table and get to work. The music is not too loud which is perfect for someone like me who needs some quiet to get anything done. I was though disappointed in the hibiscus iced tea which tasted funky and was rather pricey for a beverage. Will be coming back because it is so close but will not be ordering that iced tea!
author: Rachel N.

description:
Lower the music, people are working and on conference calls. I really enjoy the coffee here, FYI ask for it hot or you'll receive Lukewarm coffee. Coffee has cocoa and blueberry undertones and is delicious, I took a half of pound home for $15. 

- clean the tables 
- put clean spoons out 
- wipe down the station for napkins and sugar 
- fix the tables and chairs that are wobbling 
- Art up would be nice 
- get a trash can where you don't have to touch the lid. 
- lower the music volume
author: Sarah T.

description: Brilliant cafe. The coffee is fantastic, the staff are friendly and the wifi is super-fast (done a lot of work here)! Also the bathroom is revolutionary, no hands!!
author: Nick F.

description:
Great place near my office.  Noce rustic atmosphere with friendly service.  We just went there to get a coffee and chat.  

Highly recommend the Jostel Gandi.  Have them cut back on the syrup if you dont like really really sweet taste.
author: P.Y. H.

description: It is a good coffee and a really nice venue. Nothing much to explain. It is one of the bests around the area.
author: Rafael M.

description:
If you're driving, there's parking around here for 1 hour.

The vibe here was great, and I would say that their coffee and baked goods were awesome too! If you're deciding to work here, I would say that it's not the best place just because the outside noise seeps in the coffee shop easily and the music was playing quite loud. It's a great place for socializing, though!

Oh, and the baristas were friendly and engaging to the customers!
author: Aj C.

description: Good coffee. Only 1-2 plugs. Exposed brick and industrial vibe. Solid wifi. Snacks are just cookies, scones, and the like. Good for working if you don't need a plug. They have some tea options as well. Nice open space with natural light similar to Sightglass coffee, but a bit smaller. Outdoor patio!!
author: Inga C.

description: Really cool coffee place. The coffees great (I get an iced latte several times a week) and while the pricing is a bit skewed with regular coffees seeming a bit overpriced for what they are, it's worth it. I actually am spoiled by how great their coffee is- extremely smooth and rich with no butter aftertaste or acidity issues. They also have Fivestars which is great for loyalty junkies like myself.
author: Quinn Li O.

description:
If you're ever in Soma and you want to get some work done and don't mind a little walk, this is the perfect spot for you. I don't normally enjoy Chai Tea Latte's for they're a little sweet for my taste, but I decided to give it another chance, and boy did I not regret it. I would 100% recommend and order it again.

There's a limited amount of outlets, but if you charge your laptop the night before, you're in good shape! There's plenty of seats and the area is incredibly spacious. It's roughly a 10-15 walk from Civic Center Bart Station, but like I said, if you don't mind a little walk, this place is incredibly ideal to get work done at.
author: Leah C.

description:
This is the skinny: Sextant boasts a friendly staff, an attractive setting (think: exposed brick and wood table-tops), and a great, on-site roasted product.  From what I gathered, Sextant has been open for about a year and a half (someone correct me if I'm wrong).  The roaster, a young, whip-smart man, is newish to the biz, but has his eye on ever-improving his craft.  East African and So. American beans dominate the output thus far.  

The espresso they serve, tasting vaguely of blueberry and nicely balanced, makes a lovely cappuccino.  Occasionally, however, I find the espresso-and-milk drinks just a tad too hot.  I've become quite accustomed to flat whites which, temperature-wise, seem to be like Goldilocks's porridge: just right.

Sextant's pastry selection is modest.  Among the offerings were: lovely-looking cupcakes, croissants & pain au chocolates.  Other sweet treats included cookies.  I would recommend the croissant to anyone hoping for a butter-rich, flaky experience.  Dunking croissant into cappuccino was this morning's breakfast fare and brought me back to my recently-lived and now sadly over Euro-life in Switzerland.

As has been mentioned in previous reviews, Sextant is off the beaten path for many of us.  I'm somewhat hoping that that means lines will never be too long and there will always be a seat at a table.  Of course, any third-wave coffee lover would do well to visit Sextant and I should expect that this place will only become more popular over time.

*18 bucks for a 340oz bag of beans 
*lovely back patio
*free wi-fi

9.30.16 tiny update:
Cold brew is weak/water-y/off-tasting. Avoid!
author: Bea B.

description:
COFFEE AND CAKE

I've been coming in and out of this place since they have opened. They roast their beans in-house so the aroma of coffee is always escaping from the front door. I have tried their iced coffee, red eye, latte and latte with almond milk so far. All are fairly good. But today, I had their blueberry crumb cake, and MAN. OH. MAN. IT WAS DELICIOUS. 

The cake was moist and the crumbs on top were lightly sweetened with the perfect amount of crunch to make this piece the perfect snack or meal. The blueberries were relevant with the combination but I couldn't get enough of the crumbs on top. It got a bit messy, but don't worry, that's what my plate is for! It came in a HUGE slice! And it was one of the first times I couldn't finish my piece of cake by myself...I wanted to though... I really did!

On nice days, we like to sit in their back patio and enjoy the sun under the umbrellas (seems logical to me!) and on rainy days we enjoy sitting in front of their large window. The natural lighting, wooden furnishings, and brick walls will continue bringing me back as long as I'm in the area!
author: Linda K.

description: Chill coffee shop with yummy almond milk lattes. Although the bathroom threw me for a loop. I was waving my arms all over the place trying to figure out how to open the door.
author: Elle B.

description:
This is one of those hipster cafes that you'd see and automatically assume would have amazing coffee and Instagram-worthy latte art. Well, check and check! Sextant definitely did not disappoint.

The cafe has a super chill vibe - brick walls, cute lights, and soft indie music playing in the background. It's also extremely spacious which makes hanging out there very pleasant as you don't get people trying to squeeze past you like in some other cafes. If indoor seating is not your thing, there's also a cute outdoor patio you can check out if the weather is good! We wanted to sit outside but the chairs were all wet from the previous night's rain. 

The baristas were friendly and patient while we were deciding on our order. I honestly don't know why it took us that long to decide since they don't have a huge selection. We ended up getting a latte and a café au lait - both were excellent and left us fully satisfied. There's no doubt that they brew some good quality beans! I'll definitely go back if I visit SF again.
author: Karen C.

description:
-Coffee snobs who yell at customers

After charging a dollar extra because "Folsom Street Fair!", the owner and their hot headed barista refused to issue a refund for a watery cold brew, literally arguing with me, their customer, that I didn't even buy the coffee there. The screamy barista literally told off my husband, saying that we were "just trying to return it because we didn't like it and that that's a 'dick-ish' move." (Classy!) No kween, just smile and ask me how you can improve my experience with your product. This is a business, so save the attitude for after work and your foul mouth for the fair. 

At the end of the argument they reeeeeally needed to make the point to me and themselves several times that they were voted "BEST coffee in the Bay Area," right before they politely told us to "just get out." (Queue slow clap.) Guess what guys, no one cares about what hipster website blew you. Hipster cred will get you nowhere unless you have common decency and serve the people who actually pay for your shitty coffee.
author: Cynthia W.

description:
YUM! 

This place has great coffee! and not much else. Thus, they even let you bring your own food in because they don't offer any. I'm looking forward to watching their business grow. Our office is not too far away, so it's nice to drop by, it's got a great chill ambience inside that will put you at ease and they coffee will fuel you to keep you going.
author: Annie S.

description:
I live nearby, so I'm often here in the morning. I always order a latte, so I can't speak to the quality of the pour-overs, chais and such. The lattes are excellent. If I have any quibbles, it's that they serve them a little less hot than I like them, but this is a trend I've noticed in all the better coffee houses. As a rule, it seems, the better the coffee, the more lukewarm the milk. 

The interior, as others have noted, is that exposed brick style that feels both comfortable and too hip for its own good. Reading the other reviews, you'll notice that the music and its volume can vary wildly. I've been in there when there's no music playing (nice), and when there's hip hop playing at ear-splitting volume (not nice). Usually it's not too bad though. 

For the laptop warriors, the WiFi is pretty good. It's better in the back of the space than in the front. As others have noted, there are not many outlets, so if your laptop won't hold a charge--first, shame on you for always using it plugged in, which probably caused the problem in the first place--you might want to go around the corner to DNA Pizza, which also has WiFi and plenty of outlets. 

They have a good assortment of pastries, although these change from time to time. As of this writing, the scones are ginger, which are decidedly inferior to the previous fruit scones, but that could change tomorrow, so don't base your visit on the pastries you read about here. 

Having talk to the various baristas, I can tell that Sextant really cares about the coffees they serve, and make sure the baristas are well-versed in the products. I have to assume the reviewers whining that their coffee was "too weak" either received an anomaly, or are so Starbucks damaged they wouldn't know good coffee if it bit them. These guys know coffee.
author: Jim M.

description: I like. I've passed this place 1000 times but never thought to stop in and try it out. I'm glad I did. The barista was warm & friendly and her perfectly made latte kicked off a perfect Saturday!
author: Nick S.

description:
Great coffee, decent work environment, great prices, great vibe.

My only complaint would be that the tables are small to work on, and there are no power outlets anywhere except at one table.
author: Nishant G.

description: Great service and great coffee in a chic industrial setting. There's always tables and chairs available in case you need to sit down and get some work done.
author: Emily G.

description:
I am a coffee importer and visit lots of coffee shops on a daily basis. I have to say, I had the best latte ever at Sextant coffee Roasters this last Friday.
The staff is super welcoming and friendly, but bwoy these people can brew!!
author: Edward K.

description:
I go here occasionally because it's got an outdoor space to have coffee, which is less common than one would think in the city, and it's often pretty empty on the weekends. The coffee is fine, nothing special, and some of the staff are pleasant. 

The main issues with this place have to do with the fact that it seems to be owned and/or managed by someone who really doesn't care. It's almost an interesting interior but they either ran out of money for a the renovation or really think that the gas station rest stop ambiance of the bathroom and the unfinished look of the roasting area and office add "charm".

Other than that, they don't seem to understand upselling. Coffee places make a lot of money from selling additional food. There's never more than maybe a dozen total items (not a dozen different types of items) in their case, and they're usually sold out of them. Another business would take the constant selling out of items as an indicator that they should have more. And it's only a minority of times that they have non-sugar sweeteners available. If you're diabetic, you'd better not want anything in your coffee other than milk. And hey, refills of their very small cups of coffee are full price, $3.00. That's right. What looks to be about a 12 ounce mug of coffee is $3 and the refills cost the same as the first cup. Seriously, the owner is a really bad businessman, intent on squeezing nickels out of customers without providing a pleasant atmosphere. 

Again, I go here sometimes because this is the only coffee place I've been to in the city that is regularly pretty empty on the weekends. At most coffee places, I have to get lucky to get a seat. Again, another business would take that as an indication to change something. Not this one.
author: K S.

description:
Came here on the suggestion of a friend, after a group of us grabbed brunch nearby at Azucar, and ordered myself an ice latte, which, if you can trust the taste of a man who only drinks coffee once every couple months, was enjoyable.

The space itself was pretty empty, but neat in that modern warehouse-ish way that SoMa often is. Nice place to chill and lounge with friends or to get some work done, if you're in the area.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - Super spacious, plenty of seating, with nothing that should pose an accessibility issue.

Bathroom - From what I remember, their bathrooms were down a flight of steps, which is not the best thing when you're at a venue that's meant to fill your bladder!
author: Johnny W.

description:
This place is new, I think ... since it wasn't here in the SOMA area the last few years I visited. I love that they roast their coffee in house and have a good variety of offerings at any one time. 

When I don't get a latte, I tend to end up with a pour over or similarly time consuming coffee, and although they only had one person working the coffees came fast for my party of four and everything was pretty well done. They use La Strada and the whole place is very rustic, warehouse-ish, hipster and has plenty of tables and chairs for you to do work in. A new hot spot for those one-two people start-ups in SF.

I think this place is a worth while visit if you're a coffee fanatic because they are still definitely trying things out so you can get interesting flavors sometimes.
author: Lorrie M.

description: Great coffee shop to work in while in SoMa. They have a small menu but the coffee and cookies are good and they also have wifi. It's a spacious coffee shop.
author: Jessie V.

description:
Great place for Saturday and Sunday mornings to get a ton of work done in peace and quiet. No loud music or frills. The wi-fi connection is fantastic, and the coffee is top notch. 

The only drawback is the beautiful brick wall that has doesn't have enough outlets. Make sure you charge your devices to 100 before heading out here.
author: Priti K.

description: I really like the vibe of this place - on the quieter side, brick walls, airy, bright. I came here on a Sunday morning and got an iced latte. It was pretty strong and not too milky - just the way I like it! I like that it isn't one of those super popular coffee places in the city that gets overly crowded with people who only go there for the purpose of Instagramming their coffee. Good place in SoMa.
author: Steph V.

description: Was on my way to sightglass but decided last minute to stop here grab a parking spot right in front. Cool space. Offered a lot of Ethiopian coffee which I love. Looks like a nice place to study or relax.
author: Danny P.

description: Great work/study spot, low-key and quiet, with some outlets here and there, and free WiFi. Wood and metal, brick walls, industrial feel. Coffee is not amazing, but still okay. Cold brew is very watered down, both times I've had it. Agree with other comments that the restroom could use a little facelift.
author: Ashley S.

description: I came in to buy a bag of their coffee to make at home. I was greeted and treated well until I asked if they could ground the beans for me. His attitude changed after I asked. The barista made such a big deal about it and acted like he was breaking a rule for doing it and doing me a huge favor. He said that coffee beans should only be grounded as you use them which I totally get but that should be up to me, and I shouldn't be shamed for asking my coffee beans to be grounded. Not everyone wants to ground their coffee in the morning. He said to buy a grinder at target and then ignored me and walked away. This is my first time buying their coffee but I doubt I'll want to come back. There are plenty of other coffee roasters around town.
author: Christine R.

description:
Shoulders nudging, horns honking, odd smells wafting, vagrants begging ... SF is the new NYC. 

Then I step off the street into Sextant. It's clean. The staff are jovial. It's like a different country in here. Relaxed. Upbeat, yet peaceful. It should just be called "The Oasis."

I can't speak to the coffee ... I've only had tea here so far.
author: Forrest I.

description: Great atmosphere: large amount of seating area indoors, outdoor fenced in patio, generally hip music, brick walls, lots of natural light, some window seating, and friendly staff. Good selection of pastries including scones, muffins, and cookies. Tasty cold brew! Handsome hipster staff and diverse clientele. My only complaint is the wifi can be touchy, but that's small issue compared to the rest. Highly recommended!
author: William W.

description:
I work down the street from Sextant and it is the the go-to coffee spot for the office. I have been there 75-100 times. Here are my thoughts.

Pros:
-- Wonderful ambiance, well designed, lots of space and comfortable, has a back patio area
-- The coffee is good, not the best I've had, but very good

Cons:
-- They are consistently understaffed, resulting in long wait times and poor customer service
 -- 8 out of10 times they do not have the items listed on their menu, including some of their specialty drinks (e.g., Espresso Collins) and just a regular iced/cold brew coffee, which is the only thing I order
-- Most importantly, and what has compelled me to write a review, about 8-10 months ago they changed the size of their cold drink cups from a 16 ounce to a 12 ounce. At the time they told me they had run out of the bigger cups, the following week when I asked they said it was the same amount of coffee as the old cups because they use less ice (it's not) and that it was the owners choice to use the smaller cups. I asked if it was now $3 instead of the usual $4 and the answer was no, still 4 bucks. In short, today I go to the new coffee spot at Mission and 9th (Coffee Cultures) because they too have good coffee, they give me more of it (16 oz cup), and it is cheaper at $3.50. 

This may sound petty, but when I am offering repeat business in one of the most competitive business markets in the country, the little things count. Take it for what it's worth.
author: Trevor H.

description:
Coffee, service, ambiance, wifi : all solid. Nice and clean. 

Would love to see more space.
author: Anthony B.

description:
This is a seriously hidden gem! It's in a part of SoMa that is super industrial and full of warehouse stores, interspersed with restaurants and bars here and there. Given the industrial nature of the neighborhood, I wasn't surprised that this place does their own roasting. You can see all of the roasting equipment in the back.

The environment is very spacious with basically just one line of tables along the exposed brick wall. There is free wi-fi. Given the location, it was never very packed which was awesome since I came in to do work.

The coffee is great too. The coffee is not as pricey as it is in some of the more premium neighborhoods in the city, which is a plus. The one downside is that it's not the easiest neighborhood to get to, nor is there much to see or do in the area during the day.
author: Jeffrey Z.

description: Off the beaten path, low key, roaster in the neighborhood. Came in right before closing and got a cold brew. Nice La Strada machine up front and the roasting operations in the back. A patio is at the very end in addition the small seating they have up front. Folks are pretty friendly and working as a labor of love for coffee. Too bad theyre not open later. Always good to see a good new option for caffeine.
author: Kim N.

description: This is an awesome local coffee shop that roasts their own brew. The chai latte is really delicious and the drip coffee is of definite quality. I was walking in the area with my girlfriend and decided to stop by, to our surprise being a very quaint and charming experience. Recommend if you're nearby
author: Diego A.

description:
Sextant is in the corner of nowhere. hard to find parking for this spot. many tables, leisurely drinking.....relaxed ambience. patio too.

drip: house drip (12 oz,? 3)
-brew has slight herbal/exotic taste.
probably great as a cappuccino
-brew thats getting used to
-pour overs (4)

drips:
-service quick, coffee premade.
-cute barristas here
author: Victor G.

description:
It was dark inside. 

The Americano tasted bad and cost $3. 

There was modern pop music that I did not like.

I might go back for the WiFi, because there are no other cafes around.
author: Garrett S.

description:
I only got a scone and a blueberry almond granola bar. I was actually trying to get something from a nearby bakery for breakfast while staying at a hotel nearby before heading to my workplace for the day, but that bakery was not open though Apple maps had said it would be. I was happy to find Sextant Coffee Roasters instead. 
I bought the berry scone, which was thankfully not too sweet, and the granola bar, which actually has chocolate on the bottom that you can't really see even though the packaging is clear. There are a lot of calories in the granola bar--300, while I'm used to the smaller Quaker ones that are only around 100 calories each. I did like the almonds in the granola bar, though; you won't get those in the low cal Quaker ones.
Overall, I'd walk to Sextant again.
author: Liz V.

description:
Flavorful house brew with a great finish. Sometimes coffee has good aroma when you first sip it, but then once it coats the tongue, there's not much flavor. But this house brew left a wonderfully rich taste on my tongue. Probably one of the best cups I've had in a while. And this is even after it cooled off a bit, so I was impressed.  Coffee gets 5 stars.

One minor annoyance was that the barista never announced to me that my cup was ready. He just left it sitting there behind the counter (as I sat down at a table), letting it get cold. After 10 minutes or so, he finally told me that the cup was ready and he was waiting for me to pay for it. After paying for it, he handed me a warmish cup of coffee. 

If you wanted me to pay for it ahead of time, then tell me. Instead you continued to fiddle with your machine, giving me no indication that you will be expediently pouring me a cup of your already brewed coffee, so I assumed that you would bring it to me because I told you I would drink it here. You should never hand a customer coffee that is barely warm.  Sorry, service gets only 3 stars.
author: Matt L.

description: Nice coffee with a cause. Some seating and wifi, but not super comfy to spend a day working, which is fine by me.
author: Shelley W.

description: I have dropped my car in Castco to have its tires changed. They said it takes about 2 hours. What do you do if you wanna spend 2 hours of your life waiting? Have coffee in a neat place and chill? Right! This place's two blocks away from Costco (which I found my best closest option), cool environment, super nice staff, try it next time you wanna change your tires.
author: Ali Y.

description: Friendly people but the coffee is so so. Cappuccino's foam is too dry and way to much milk. Ambiance is great!
author: Valerie W.

description:
Spacious. Good coffee and wifi. Definitely a good option. U fortunately the baristas tend to be quite talkative. After hearing for the 5 th time her lament about her roommate broadcasted to everyone in the cafe we went elsewhere to get work done.
The neighborhood is a bit sketch so don't leave stuff in your car if you drove here.
author: Vinay K.

description: Now that they changed something about the brew process it's one of my favorite morning coffee spots. Just wish they had more yummy food options
author: shoddy l.

description:
I love coffee, so I feel quite lucky to live in a city where I can walk for 15 minutes and find 5+ excellent coffee roasters who roast right here in the city. 

Now I have one literally around the corner from where I live. Sextant just had their soft opening this Monday (end of May 2014) and they're showing great promise so far. The decor of the space reminds me a bit of Four Barrel or Sightglass with the addition of a nice outdoor patio. 

They are adding new features every day (and they're also looking for people that know their way around an espresso machine, so if you're a barista looking for a place to hone your skills, they want to talk with you). They do offer wifi and have plenty of seating, so it looks like a nice place to get some daytime work done. 

Right now they're open from 7 am to 2 pm every day, but they say they'll be open until 6 pm once they've hired some new baristas. 

If all of them can pull an espresso shot as well as Scottie, they'll be in great shape!
author: Brian B.

description: Great coffee and food but.... A coffee shop with only 2 tables with outlets? Unacceptable  for the modern world. After paying $10 for food and coffee I was forced to go to Phil's coffee just so I could get some work done.
author: Chris R.

description:
Something a little strange about this place. 
Can't put my finger on it. 
I can tell it operates a little outside the realm of the trendiest roasters.
Something about how their website remains stuck in a "new website coming soon" mode since the beginning makes me wonder if they are in some sort of trouble in this crazy San Francisco coffee war. Can they compete with Sightglass and Blue Bottle? Can they sell enough coffee to pay insane SF rent prices? 
Looks like somebody put up a lot of money to get this place off the ground - pro equipment, vintage probat coffee roaster, hip space. But now that it's up and running, something in the air feels a little incomplete.

But then here's the strangest part - the coffee I've had here is surprisingly good. 
Carefully hand-brewed house roasted single origin coffee made using Hario V-60 paper filter cones. I bought a bag of their blend of various Ethiopian origin beans. When I brewed this at home it was pretty darn good - flavorful light/medium roast. 

I feel like this would be the best coffee roaster in Sacramento or Topeka or something. Somehow in San Francisco's crowded specialty coffee market it may be relegated to an ordinary neighborhood cafe. 
I'm curious to see what's going to happen with this place. 
How many coffee roasters have the word "sex" in the name? They should capitalize on this somehow.
author: RK W.

description:
I have no idea why everybody rates this place so high. 
I ordered an Americano and a Mocha. The price for both drinks was $10. Wow!

When the drinks came out the mocha was about 8 fluid ounces and the Americano was about 5 fluid ounces. They also don't have Splenda. 

If this place is considered good in SF I'd really hate to try a bad place.
author: B C.

description:
Great coffee. Solid baristas. Chilled out space. Wish it were open late.

Restroom cleanliness could use an upgrade.
author: noflaps c.

description: Great work cafe, nice staff, killer coffee...also there is a really cute outdoor area.
author: Mary A.

description:
Drip coffee: baristas told me today's coffee was a single origin Columbian. My take: clean taste, brewed moderate-strong, nice caramel, strong citrus-y acidity -- it was enough to curdle my soymilk on contact :/ but not quite enough to turn me off to it (I'll confess I'm kinda fussy about acid in my coffee though; please enjoy a grain of salt with this review).

Baristas were hella chill. I asked their opinion on the Jostel Gandi chai-espresso drink and they gave it to me straight: if you're used to espresso and coffee only it'll be a tough one for you, and if you love a sweet chai you would probably go extra sweet on this one. I fking love getting actual information from service folx to help me with my decision and NOT getting up sold -- that's trust. That's how I measure good service.

Liked the space. Brick walls, wood and metal seating that is actually fairly comfy. Coffee Roasting gear in the back for nerds like me to gawk at. And the best part: OUTDOOR BACK PATIO complete with cute mosaic-y tables, succulent planters (duh) and shade umbrellas. No plugs outside though.

Perfect spot to curl up this foggy SF midday. Next time I'll try an espresso thing.
author: Mason H.

description:
Brand new neighbors are roasting beans and serving  excellent coffee in a vintage space.  Sources from a single Ethiopian farmer.  Plenty of seating and  a nice outdoor space. Scotty did a great cappuccino.  Not a fan of gluten free anything, but they have Kerri Kreations baked goods out of Santa Cruz and the peanut butter cookie was quite tasty.

Free WiFi

Hope to see local artists on the exposed brick walls. Rumours of a future parklet are exciting.
author: April M.

description: Super hipster industrial wood coffee space in an otherwise empty few blocks of Folsom during the day (mostly car repair shops and gay bars). Because of it's location it's not crowded so it's a great place to hang out, work, or have meetings. I didn't try their coffee but they roast their own. Instead I got the chai latte ($4 - yeah, kinda steep). It was fully of foamy milk which I liked but pretty sweet still. I would have liked more spice kick. Not sure if they make it themselves but since it was so sweet I'm guessing it comes out of a container.
author: Jean K.

description:
I'm a simple lady, and all I ask from a coffee shop are three things:
- Wifi
- Cute baristas
- Basic coffee 

Unfortunately, Sextant misses the mark on arguably the most important item: the coffee! 

Every time I take a sip, it's like I just bit into a piece of Sour Patch Kids. Their coffee is much too sour for any palate. 

Secondly, they don't have sugar substitutes. What if I was a diabetic? 

Thirdly, the service could be much more improved. At one point there was a group of spoons in a jar with no label. I grabbed one and used it to stir my coffee. Then I later learned that it was indeed a spoon retrieved from the "dirty spoons jar". No bueno.

In this economy (yes, I still have the right to say this even in 2016), Sextant has to improve it's quality across various areas, otherwise it will be doomed. Let this be a wake up call Sextant! GAHHH!!!!!!!!

(Side note: The name is dumb too. I feel dirty when I have to tell clients to meet me there...)
author: food y.

description:
Sextant Coffee Roasters is decidedly trendy in an urban chic sort of way. It's easy to imagine it filled with snapping poetry slam attendants dressed in all black. The baristas are friendly but nonintrusive, and there is no music playing to distract you from whatever you're reading. There's self-serve water, and a small backyard with two to three tables if you'd prefer to work outdoors.

Downside is that there are very few outlets on its walls of exposed brick, which might be why it was so uncrowded on a weekend. Come here with all your electronics fully charged for a quiet, undisturbed afternoon fueled by in-house roasted coffee. It's probably a good venue for an interview or to talk over business plans. I wouldn't recommend it for a date or a hang out, however, as there are cafes with more talking points and more menu options in prettier neighborhoods nearby. It also closes at 5 on weekends.
author: Varsha S.

description: Delicious almond milk latte. Very sweet  staff and patrons. I left my credit card at the counter and they chased me down before I jumped in an uber! Thank you!!!
author: Audrey R.

description:
Solid coffee experience!

-Decaf cappuccino was tasty: not bitter but still flavorful and smooth
-Barista Kelly finished it with hands down the most beautiful design of all the specialty shops I have visited in SF including Blue Bottle, Sightglass, and Mazarine
-Much quieter, calmer, and more relaxed atmosphere than the nearby (and famed) Sightglass. 
-Would be a great spot for a conversation or to work remotely.
author: Greg M.

description: Pour over was ok, but the cold brew was watered down as others have said. I'm disappointed they raised the prices from the website menu. I paid $5 for a pourover and $4 for the cold brew!
author: E T.

description:
The place looks awesome, great place to enjoy an afternoon. Has the new typical industrial style to the place, uses daylight to lit place for the most part. Lots of space for people to hang out but most tables are just enough for 2 chit-chatters or an individual with a macbook. Also I wasn't entirely sure where to look for the menu or order my coffee. Barista was very nice.

The coffee just wasn't up to my standards and took a bit too long to make. 

We tried two drinks; ICE coffee and Mocha. The coffee to both was simply too weak for my taste and the iced coffee was a bit sour? 

I'll probably come again to give it another shot as it could just have had been an off day.
author: Ian C.

description: Friendly staff up front and we so happen to visit when the roasting process was in session so we were able to witness the green beans getting their color.  The gentleman overseeing the roast was nice enough to demonstrate to my kids on how coffee was roasted and then brewed to perfection!  Great people, great coffee and a great place to just chill out for a bit.
author: Anthony E.

description: Sextant is a welcome addition to the 'hood - the still up and coming part of SoMa my neighbors affectionately call "Costco Heights". Love the space - lots of exposed brick, industrial vibe - and the staff are super friendly. The best part of all is the Jostel Gandi - a hot chai drink with espresso. It is amazing and I can't help but get one every time I'm there. The other espresso drinks are also great, but the Jostel Gandi wins.
author: Annie S.

description: The men and women behind the bar are extremely nice. A clutch coffee spot with a sunny backyard to enjoy your afternoon coffee break/short meeting.  They roast their coffee there, too - which is always a bonus if you love coffee.
author: Isa H.

description: This is a great place to study/do work! I went on a Thursday at 2:30pm. The backyard is shaded so not too hot, and has umbrellas and mosaic tables. The wifi worked very well, the coffee was delicious, and the servers were very friendly. Great atmosphere.
author: Brooke R.

description: I come here for coffee served by good people. Both are always achieved. That's all I need to say. Oh wait... & there banana bread... Oh lord. So good.
author: Asif H.

description:
I'm glad to see a cafe in this area of Folsom.  It's also great to see another roaster pop up.  

However, when I inquired about how often they roast, decaffeinated specifically, they said once a month. Now, anyone who is really into coffee and who has roasted their own, or even done so much as study coffee roasting, knows that even properly refrigerated and stored roasted coffee is past its prime in a week, due to off-gassing. Hey Sextant.. roast less at a time, just more often. 

Nevertheless, my market-rate pour over was tasty, a brightly flavored city+ roast.  Polite barista.  Cool enough space. The walls need a bit of artwork. 

(Keep your attitudes in check, lots of dinner guests prefer decaffeinated after a meal.)
author: Christopher M.

description: Absolutely LOVE this coffee shop! One of the girls in the front is HILARIOUS! She honestly gives the best energy. Didn't get her name but she really brought out this cafe! She was so friendly and always made sure we were okay. 200% above average for customer service
author: Jenel M.

description: Absolutely love this place. My coffee was very tasty, it's big, they have an outdoor patio, well designed, coffee isn't overpriced, but what struck me the most is the music choice. So good.
author: Judith S.

description:
If Sextant and nearby Four Barrel Coffee aren't owned by the same people, didn't plagiarize off each other, or together are a scientific experiment to measure sameness under different names, I'll eat my hat.  The 2 locations are very similar inside, but I'll give the edge to Four Barrel for coffee quality and choice.  Also, Sextant only has 2-person tables arranged (although I suppose you could rearrange them, they are all aligned against the wall).  The environment was pleasant - the roaster? was a bit loud at times, but what do you expect from an industrial-themed establishment? 

Pastries looked great, and for $4 they better be phenomenal.  Coffee was good overall and free Wifi made me round up a half to the 4th star.  Might return after I try others.
author: Ben K.

description:
I had a God Shot at Sextant... screamed Ethiopia. The baton has been passed... Actually I would contend Sextant is now the torchbearer in SF.
Kudos to Kinani for bringing us Ethiopia, not the cheap stuff but the real Ethiopia, most importantly making us believe again. No wonder thrillist had them in their list of best new of the nation 11/14.
author: Nasci N.

description: Having zipped by Sextant to get to Four Barrel and Ritual in the Mission, we finally stopped in for an early Sunday morning pour over coffee.  If I didn't know any better, I'd say that Sextant and Sightglass were modeled very closely after each other.  Both are based on (random) instruments, and both have beautiful modern looking spaces that allow in a fair amount of natural light.  Sextant has what appears to be a roaster all the way in the back part of the cafe, in addition to some beautiful exposed brick walls that are minimally decorated.  Both of us had pour overs with Africa beans and thought that our coffees were delicious.  The pastry selection seemed somewhat limited to cookies, but that could have been because we caught them in the early part of the morning before things had come in.  The barista wasn't the warmest person I had ever met, but she did help me figure out which coffee to get based on my preferences.  Overall, this sleepy and quiet place off Folsom was a great find and a great alternative to standing in line for some delicious coffee.
author: Lisa I.

description:
I'm giving 3 stars because the people who work there are so nice and friendly . But is it me? Their ice coffee sucks! Took 3 sips and threw it away:( wasted my $$$  someone told me their coffee is known for that sour and fermented taste :(:::: should have walked my ass down to Starbucks :( 
Do people really like the coffee tasting like that?
author: Em C.

description: Coffee and cappuccino were great. Saw a lady bring her 2 sweet dogs in and the owners were chill - I like that. They also had some new things I've never encountered before on the menu like an Espresso Collins.
author: dogdaysOsummer A.

description: I dropped into Sextant on a short walk from the Soma Streatfood park just around the corner. It has a hipster look - lots of exposed brick - and was very quiet on the Sunday afternoon when I went. I got a pourover of the Natural Konga, which was a solid cup, although I don't think their roast is quite at the level of Ritual or Blue Bottle. I'll be back again next time I'm in the area, but I don't think I'll buy a bag of their beans.
author: Sebastian M.

description: Great people and great coffee! What could be better? Seriously this place is amazing! My go to order is the Espresso Tonic (kaffe tonic) or a shot of espresso.
author: Peg A.

description: Close to work. Clean. Spacious. Cool ambience. Awesome coffee. Just some reasons why this place is fast-becoming our oasis from work during breaktime for my co-workers and I.
author: Jonathan B.

description: Cool little nook. Got a macchiato that was more on the cappuccino side than the espresso side. Wife had the hibiscus iced tea that was amazing. I was surprised that this place was so quiet. Or at least it felt that way. Anyway, great spot with great coffee.
author: Marcus R.

description: Well trained staff and really good pastries. Bring headphones-- was a bit shocked to hear Top 40s pop being played in the cafe. That's where the star was lost for me-- otherwise great spot. :)
author: Grant M.

description: Great music, service and of course coffee. Across from the huge self storage, it's a nice respite from folsomism.
author: Tracy Y.

description:
OK, to be fair and admit I messed up:  There were NOT as many 'quakers' in the batch as I thought there were.

Still, no matter how I brew the coffee, it is remarkably 'astringent'.
author: David P.

description:
This is now my favorite coffee shop and a roaster in FolSoMa!

As I entered the shop the heavenly smell of hand selected coffee from Ethiopia roasted in a cast iron roaster flooded my olfactory leaving my taste buds in a  state of salivating envy... but not for too long. 

As I approached the counter I couldn't help but notice tall, slender and elegant cold brew rig. For seven hours she has been patiently collecting droplets of ice water channeled through a thickness of freshly roasted beans that were destined to quench my thirst on an oh-so-rare hot San Francisco day. She packed a punch! I was awakened.

I let my taste buds join my olfactory in celebration of the flavor while the sun remedied my Vitamin D deficiency at the back patio.

When I came back on a grey day I was embraced by warmth of delicious and ornate cappuccino and soothing colors of bricks and wood. 

I'll be back, Sextant!

p.s. +1 for free wifi!
author: agil m.

description: Awesome coffee! I even bought two packages to take back home with me once I tried their espresso! I will definitely be coming back there again and recommend it to every coffee lover in the area.
author: Anton T.

description: That's sofa king hot! Newly opened. :) my legs though,. ;) spilled my drink. Wipe me. Like right now. I'm sofa king wet out of mind... I'm like dripping so slowly. Namm sayin.. yikes! Help dry me off,, hehe.
author: Joey B.

description:
Not quite as breathtaking an interior as a certain *cough* other SOMA coffee shop... but a very nice space. And staff gave us (actual! genuine!) smiles both times we've been in. 

They use delicious Strauss "barista" milk, which: mmmmmmyum. (Dairy geek? Here, check it, about 3/4 down the page: http://strausfamilycreamery.com/news-media/news/imbibe-magazine-the-milky-way-by-hannah-wallace) Also, unlike our other nearby fave, Vega, they are open on weekends. 

They don't (yet?) have a bike rack in front, but they very nicely let us bring our bikes inside with us on one of our visits.

I hope these guys do well and stick around, and will definitely be popping in more often.
author: Beverage Appreciato R.

description: Solid coffee shop.. Big space. Friendly service. Respectable coffee. Low key location.
author: Kerry W.

description:
I have already been to this place 5 times in one week!

Most recently, the coffee cake was massive and fresh (I shared with a friend), and the Jostel Gandi Latte was purely divine.  As a fan of Blue Bottle, Ritual Roasters, and Stumptown, I can say that the Jostel Gandi is perhaps the most enjoyable warm drink I have had in a very long time.  It is slightly spicy, thick, very warm and therapeutic, combining the herbal feel of Samovar Tea Lounge with the fresh authenticity of Ritual Roasters or BB.

Sextant's staff is warm and wonderful (like the coffee!), the interior chic and spotless, and the clientele are young, driven, and international.  Love that the place has wifi and a cute, secret outdoor patio in the back, perfect for an intimate gathering.

I will be back to Sextant many more times, and will tell a lot of friends about the unique Jostel Gandi drink, as well as the baked goods!
author: Munir J.

description:
Awesome location, great space that isn't at all crowded, and friendly staff. They also have a cute little patio out back that is pretty awesome.

Unfortunately, the prices are high and the coffee is only so so. I'll definitely give this place another shot and perhaps the coffee will be better next time, but a $3.00 iced coffee should taste fantastic, theirs didn't.

Oh, and although they do have free WiFi (which is nice), it is very slow and not altogether reliable, so not good for very much more than posting this review.
author: Charles S.

description:
These guys are right next to work, so I came here the other day (well... multiple days)...  Here are my thoughts: 

Positives (+): 
(+) Cute place, lots of tables, free wifi
(+) Coffee is good. Pour overs available. Espresso. Cafe au laite, etc. 
(+) You get larger amounts of coffee if you have it "for here", versus to-go

Negatives (-): 
(-) To Go coffee sizes are TINY! And only one size options

I'll definitely be back, and I'll definitely have to try a pastry at some point. As well as many of the other coffee drinks.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Overall, the coffee is pretty good. I usually get the iced latte which is delicious for a warm summer day. But today, the weather was a bit nippier so I opted for a regular latte. The coffee is smooth, and just as delicious warm, HOWEVER, the only reason I am not giving this place a full 5 stars is because my coffee was luke warm, borderline cold.

That is something that really irks me. If i'm ordering a coffee, I expect it to be warm. I think the baristas can do a better job at steaming the milk for a minute longer, rather than haphazardly putting luke warm milk into my espresso. Next time, i'm going to ask them for an extra hot latte, in hopes that it actually comes out warm.
author: Moniza M.

description: Granted we were there as soon as they opened their doors on a Sat morning, barista was not on his A game. He was only person behind bar, macchiato was sloppy and when pour over was delivered to us, temperature was luke warm which means it was poured at a very low temperature  and mot extracted adequately. Not impressed overall.
author: Julia P.

description: An amazing coffee shop with a great understanding of what great coffee really is. Even the newer baristas are able to pull an amazing cup of espresso that is smooth and rich with no bitter or negative notes. For someone who really enjoys a great cup of espresso with no accoutrements, this is a breath of fresh air!
author: Æron D.

description: Fantastic little coffee shop located in an interesting part of SOMA right by a bunch of different auto body shops. Free wifi, nice work space (although the tables are too small to fit two laptops). Good strong coffee. Parking might be a bit of a challenge as most of it is metered parking.
author: Betty C.

description: Friendly staff! When I was there they were roasting their beans (did I mention they roast their own beans?!) and it gave the place a great coffee smell. Your usual mix of people meeting and working on laptops - there was plenty of places to sit inside and outside.
author: Clare C.

description: This shop was exactly as I imagined a San Francisco should be. The look was industrial with exposed brick and raw wood. There were plenty of tables to choose from. I ordered an iced Americano which was perfectly pulled. I have recommended this shop to friends that are travelling soon.
author: Stephen B.

description:
This place is great. 

I ordered the chai tea latte and it is so, so, so perfect! others have mentioned the temperature of the beverage, but I thought it was great that I could drink it right away, as opposed to a scalding drink i'd have to wait 15 minutes before drinking. 

they have wifi here, not very crowded, and clean! I really like the interior design including the brick walls, the wood counter, and the ambiance. 

the only thing they're missing is pastries! for breakfast they had cookies and a caramel cake. Not exactly what I have in mind. how about bagels? and maybe add a sandwich or salad to the menu?? :)
author: Eve V.

description:
The coffee is good, but the size is tiny. I think it was probably 6 oz.

There is a reasonable amount of indoor seating, and it is not too loud. I didn't see much in the way of things to eat.
author: Jeremy M.

description:
Strolled over to this awesome spot with the wife after filling our belly's at a near by burger joint.

The place is brand new and didn't have a lot of customers, but it's a gloomy day so peoples are probably staying at home and making babies.

There is a roaster in the back of the location as well as an outdoor area. I really dig the vibe here.

This spot really reminds me of some of the coffee spots I used to frequent when I lived in LA.

The wife got her typical latte and I ordered a single espresso to see test the skill and flavor of their offerings.

The barista pulled the first shot and noticed it wasn't up to par, so they put that off to the side. The other dude behind the counter grabbed the discarded shot and slung it back to see why the shot was not served to me. He nodded at the other guy in support of his decision.

They adjusted the machine and pulled two more shots before giving me my actual shot. Yes this added some time to get my espresso, but I fully appreciate the fact they didn't want to give me a crappy espresso.

After my shot was served I wiggled on over to our table and sampled the espresso. It was on point. I should also mention that this place also offers soda water with the espresso which a lot of other shops in the city do not do.

I will totally be coming back to this spot when I'm in the area.
author: Jerry H.

description: Great great coffee! Reminds me of Melbourne Australia! The guy working making the coffe was so sweet and friendly would def come back!
author: Rita A.

description: You might wanna chose better who you hire. The guy that was guarding the door during folsom street fair was very rude. My friends and I went to get coffee and I was waiting for them outside, according to him I was blocking the sign (which is on the public street) so the guy ordered me to move, I moved back a few feet and again he ordered me to move again because apparently  now I was blocking the door.  And then once more when I moved again. I understand that you don't want the pathway blocked but there are ways to say it and ask politely if I could move, not ordering me and being rude.
author: Daniel B.

description: It's a nice place but if you need to work for a couple hours it's way too cold. I guess in a warm day would be ok but this is SF people!
author: Samuele M.

description:
Just moved into the area a month ago and have been tasting all of the different coffee houses in SOMA. This mocha is by far the best coffee beverage I have ever tasted (hint: you can actually taste the chocolate!) The place is huge with an open floor plan and high ceilings, the ambiance is nice with tall windows and exposed brick, the barista is gorgeously well manicured, professional and very friendly who makes beautiful patterns with the foam and fantastic drinks. 
I will definitely be going back frequently!
author: Nicolas D.

description: Nice place to hang out and work for a few hours. Nothing special about their coffee, but gave them a 4 for being fairly quiet place, and having uncommonly large amounts of seating space - including a small courtyard area out back.
author: Jordon W.

description:
- coffee delicious!
- interior spacious and well designed
- pastries are delicious. vegan options are fantastic as well
- service very friendly and kind

Support this new place!
author: Lo P.

description: Appalling customer service. I don't understand the need for rudeness or attitude toward paying customers? It was pretty chilly in there as it's cold and rainy outside, so I kindly asked the female barista if I could shut the door. Her response in her snotty tone was, "I guess it's ok." Um...ok... Not sure what that means. I proceeded to sit down. She immediately went and opened the door back up. It was like she was looking for fight or a challenge. It's sad when someone works in the service business with that pitiful chip on their shoulder. If I were the business owner, she'd be let go immediately with that puss face. It's not worth the fight. But I'll never spend another penny there and neither will my friends. The bathroom needs a vat of bleach too. Good luck with your future, little girl.
author: Sally S.

description: Maybe they just caught me at the right moment, but this was one of the best cappuccinos I've had in a long while.  Service was fast and very friendly.   Space was awesome.  Location is a bit odd, but I'd travel here just to get a cup!
author: Matt V.

description: Amazing service. No snobbery, which I find usually comes with these kind of hipster coffee shops. No it is not cheap, but the 5 stars is for the taste and the service. I'd pay extra for the good feeling. The people working here are just good, nice people who want to give you a good cup with a smile. I will be returning.
author: Lane M.

description: Nice style inside, friendly service, good coffee. I'm going with 2 starts though because I think their pricing is too high for what they offer. It's not a fancy part of town, the ambiance isn't cozy nor beyond your average mod coffee bar. I ordered a coffee and almond croissant. $7... $3 for the small mug of coffee, $4 for the pastry. The pastry was good but didn't expect the fruit cheese center, it just looked like an average almond croissant. I could've asked though. I finished my single cup of coffee and went to ask about refills. No comp refills, no discount, it's just another $3. I'd go back if they're pricing improved and if they addressed some kind of coffee refill perk. But no plans to return for now, I'll find another spot while my car gets worked on at the shop.
author: Steve A.

description: Love the coffee here. Best in the city. Delicious. My favorite place in San Francisco
author: Tony S.

description: Loved the outside patio.  It's a mellow hip little refuge from the hectic surroundings.  And the coffee is good.
author: Silvana B.

description: Mmmmmm! Their Jostel Ghandi -- a spicy, flavorful take on your usual dirty chai -- is out of this world good. Baristas always seem like awesome people. The back patio is cozy and quiet and usually sunny. A nice get away in this industrial part of town.
author: Brittany F.

description: Huge space for eating or studying! Their jostel gandhi (dirty chai) was so good! Def coming back when it's sunny so I can sit outside
author: Page F.

description: I came looking for a quiet moment and a nice cup of cappuccino. I found them here at Sextant. Kinani thank you.
author: Getachew A.

description: Great double shot of espresso, expertly pulled, and from really nicely roasted Ethiopian beans. I usually don't like single origin espressos, because espressos should be blends with different layers of complexity, right?! But they pull this shit off. Chugged my sparkling water and sipped that espresso so the taste lingered in my mouth. #itsgettingweird
author: Ted M.

description: Old drip coffee and awful espresso. In this city where the coffee bar is very high, this place can't even register.
author: Aruna P.

description: Coffee's great. Lot's of seating. Table tops and chair tops are a delightful wood grain.
author: Jasper C.

description: This place is amazing. Unfortunately it isn't located near anything worthwhile, but bygones. Great laid back atmosphere. Plenty of open space and seating. Acceptable noise levels. And best of all, they use chocolate syrup in their mocha. It's a nice surprise waiting for me on the bottom. "Oh, there you are chocolate burst. I wondered why I paid the extra $0.50."
author: Lams L.

description: Was so excited to try this coffee shop during my last weekend as a resident of the neighborhood, but it's closed on weekends! Couple that with the fact that it's already located a bit off the beaten path, and I won't be heading in any time soon. It's a shame, because the only other options in the area are Peet's and Starbucks, and I would totally root for a business like this to succeed.
author: Laura H.

description: Loved it! Strong with a smooth finish. Just wish they had bigger sizes, I want more! May just have to ditch the long lines at Blue Bottle and call this one my hands down new favorite!
author: Josie C.

description: Nice open space, great back patio, friendly and fast service, delicious coffee. I'll be back!
author: Michael D.

description: Sure, maybe their coffee isn't as good as what you can get at the crowded steaming inferno that is Sightglass, but it's pretty damn good. And you can actually drink it comfortably, in a seat, while browsing the web, for free, without feeling like you're being boiled alive. Win! It's a pretty location, with plenty of seating, a great little patio in the back and great service. They lose a star on their horrible horrible cookies though. They taste like sugar coated cardboard and have the consistency of stale bread.
author: Nat V.

description: More like 3.5 stars. I don't really drink coffee so I can't exactly comment on the quality of the drinks. It's a cool looking open space, and they have free wi-fi. But it does get pretty noisy so not ideal for working. The back patio is quieter, but no outlets.
author: Jimmy K.

description: Awesome new roaster in SOMA. Excellent, distinct espresso roast. Not the same chocolate bomb that the rest of SF is roasting, but rather a wonderful new approach with hints of cherry, meyer lemon, and a natural sweetness that I haven't tasted anywhere else. Will definitely become a respected player in the SF coffee scene.
author: Jesse N.

description: Beautiful coffee, beautiful space. Very wonderful people. I guess sightglass is probably the big player for fancy coffee in this neighborhood. Sextant does somewhat darker roasts, and also blends a bit, so if super-light-roast single-origin isn't your thing please give these guys a try!
author: Wangston P.

description: Too many other coffee options in the area. This one suffers by comparison. Otherwise it's a solid spot. The baked goods were commercial. If they do roast their own coffee it's pretty tasty. Definitely better than some other big spots. The reason I am even writing about this spot is I think it might be the first fo-cobbler/hipster spot I've found. Wood paneling made of pallets-check. Old school sound system-check. All the fancy brewing machines-yup. Still feels like a front in there. Maybe that makes it more interesting.
author: Darius L.

description: $3 for a drip coffee that wasn't very good and the cup was small for the price. There was no artificial sweetener available. I told the counter staff I am diabetic and they suggested I use the sugar water that was there, which is just plain stupid.
author: Don T.

description: Ok how can a coffee and tea house not have honey to accompany its Earl Grey tea?!  Just sayin'!
author: Kent N.
